author: Pau Garcia i Quiles
message:
The problem with the new layout for KMix is it does not match the expressions we use in human language, at least in English, Spanish or Catalan. In these languages, we use the expression "turn up/down the volume" to mean "increase/decrease the volume".

In addition to that, moving the slider left is usually perceived to mean "keep volume on the left speaker at 100% and decrease the volume on the right speaker accordingly". Idem for moving slider right.

IMHO that makes the new layout very ununtuitive.

replies.author: TheBlackCat
replies.message: There is also the issue that he mute buttons don't look like buttons, so it would not be outlandish to think that they represent the end of the slider where there is no sound. So moving towards the right would mean reducing the volume, when it really means increasing it. This, of course, would reverse and would be correct if the sound wasn't muted. But it would be nice if there was some clear way to indicate which end is high volume and which end is low volume.

replies.author: Andrei
replies.message: I agree with this. In my oppinion, in kmix the plaback devices and playback streams could be merged together. This would reduce the number of tabs to only two, which i find more manageable.

replies.author: Elvis Stansvik
replies.message: I agree. And also I find it much easier to move the slider with high fidelity with my mouse if it is vertical. I mean it's easier to control my arm movements when moving the mouse up/down instead of right/left.

replies.author: Aurélien
replies.message:
I agree we use the expression "turn up/down", but on the other hand most of our real world volume controls are potentiometers (with the notable exception of mix tables). So if we were to replicate real world we would have to use QDial widgets, which would not be very easy to use.

Horizontal sliders to adjust volumes are not a new idea. You can find them in GNOME, Mac OS X, YouTube. Maybe the slider need some muted and loud icons around them like there is on Mac OS? (See this screenshot)

I personally think both orientations are usable, but KMix now comes with a few tabs. We could argue on whether all these tabs are needed but it's too late to get rid of them for KDE SC 4.6. Given this constraint, I think the interface looks better if all tabs are visible. This means the window gets quite wide. Since most tabs usually contain only one or two sliders, it makes more sense to orient them horizontally, as it makes a better use of the available space.

replies.author: Jan Molnár
replies.message:
I agree with the article, but I also do not agree with the horizontal slider. There are many reasons:
Recently I switched to PulseAudio, but before that I had a lot of sliders (10?) in each tab, horizontal sliders would be a huge wasting of space.
It's a little bit annoying to move the slider such a long distance (downscaling would solve it, of course).
It looks like a slider for left/right speaker (Pau Garcia i Quiles).
It’s easier to control arm movements up/down instead of right/left (Elvis Stansvik).
Do not consider me to be a troll, I really love the other changes you have made, but I would like to point these facts (in my opinion) to improve it a little bit more. Good job!

replies.author: Aurélien
replies.message:
> Recently I switched to PulseAudio, but before that I had a lot of sliders (10?) in each tab, horizontal sliders would be a huge wasting of space.
When there are more than one sliders, they stack on top of each others so I don't see how it wastes space.

> It looks like a slider for left/right speaker (Pau Garcia i Quiles).
Do you feel like you are adjusting the balance when adjusting the volume of a YouTube video?

> It’s easier to control arm movements up/down instead of right/left
I would love to read a study proving this. I don't think it is so evident, otherwise all sliders in all user interfaces would be oriented vertically. I don't think it is a question of precision, but rather a question of habit: we have been using vertical sliders in mixer for years so it feels weird to try another orientation.

replies.author: Pau Garcia i Quiles
replies.message:
> Do you feel like you are adjusting the balance when adjusting the volume of a
> YouTube video?

In the volume control of YouTube videos there is a triangle which grows from left to right. That makes quite clear you are increasing the volume. Maybe adding that triangle is the solution for KMix?

replies.author: Aurélien
replies.message: I don't see any growing triangle on YouTube volume control, but I think you mean something like the Amarok 1.4 volume slider. That could be a good idea indeed.

replies.author: Jan Molnár
replies.message: I like this solution. I would also like something else which would express decreasing volume on the left side and increasing volume in the right side (the Mac OS way is OK). The problem is both of these solutions are still vertically space wasting (see the Mac OS picture) which is multiplied by unused space on sides of sliders.

replies.author: Jan Molnár
replies.message:
1) Display is usually much wider than higher, in my case it is 800x1280 (and there is a horizontal panel, which cannot be also counted), having more than a few sliders would lead to vertical scrolling (which would be a pain multiplied by free space on left and right margin of the sliders).
2) I am used to horizontal sliders, I have been using computers for a while, in my opinion it is a quite good solution (maybe not so intuitive but space saving) bellow video box, but our case is another scenario. It is probably seen differently by new users and experienced users.
3) I can ask someone from our Department of Interaction, but I do not see them much often.

replies.author: Aurélien
replies.message:
> I can ask someone from our Department of Interaction, but I do not see them much often.
I would be very interested in such an information!

replies.author: Jan Molnár
replies.message:
Finally I wrote them an email and this morning I got a long reply. Here are some main points:
There are studies focused on Fitt's law (Analysis of cursor movements with a mouse, Effects of angle of approach on cursor movement with a mouse: Consideration of Fitts' law), which don't prove my statement. I was probably wrong, but these studies are focused on Fitts' law which is not exactly the same, we are talking about (Fitts' law is focused on many criterion, but we have another metrics - e.g. we need to be more precise).
Horizontal movements seems to be faster.
There is a significant difference between horizontal/vertical and diagonal movements.
My hypothesis could be backed up by the fact, that we use only fingers (thumb, ring/little finger) for vertical movements and the whole wrist for horizontal movements.

replies.author: Markus

"Indeed, running KDE under another language is a good advice (which I must confess I should follow more often)"

Developers should always set their workspace language to "x-test". It simply adds "xx" at the beginning and end of every string.

"I plan to write a post about reducing waste of space in dialogs, which can be help to keep them to a reasonable size, even if it does not solve all problems."

Mac OS X's preference windows resize automatically. Firefox also has that feature when "browser.preferences.animateFadeIn" is set to true (performance is bad under Linux, though, but still gives the right idea when one doesn't know Mac OS X).
That has the advantage that dialogs grow accordingly when a language has longer strings.
Wasted space is also usually not a problem then.

author: Robert Knight
message:
Hi Aurelien,

For the columns, we implemented a variation of QHeaderView that supports the concept of 'stretch factors' that are seen in Qt's layouts, this lets us specify that space should be divided up in certain proportions within the current viewport space (eg. 1/3rd, 1/3rd, 1/6th, 1/6th). If the user resizes the header manually, the proportions are saved rather than the actual size, so if the viewport size changes, the saved proportions are applied to the new viewport size.

Code at http://www.mendeley.com/cli...

replies.author: Aurélien
replies.message: Thanks for sharing Robert. Stretch factors is something I was surprised was not implemented in header views, given that such a concept exists in layouts. I will have a look at it, but this may probably be too intrusive for 4.6.

author: apol
message: The correct way to provide a default size is to reimplement QWidget::sizeHint, not to call resize... at least it's what i've always seen in the doc and in the end, it makes sense.

replies.author: Aurélien
replies.message: You are right. I reworked this paragraph to only mention sizeHint(). It should be more accurate now.

replies.author: Parker
replies.message: Since we're talking about initial default window sizes, an even simpler solution than reimplementing sizeHint() is to just pass a default size to KXmlGuiWindow::setupGui(). This size is used when the launching an app the first time with an empty configuration. Of course setting a size hint might also be a good idea, but in many cases giving a default size is enough, if your app is KXmlGuiWindow based.

author: Jan Kundrát

Dear Aurelien, it was cool to read the article, up from the very first sentecne almost to the end. I absolutely agree that it takes time to set up size hints properly, and was caught by how hard is to set up a QListView reasonably. BTW, it's really recommended to call setUniformRowHeights() if you use lazy loading from the model).

However, I do have a serious problem with the proposed redesign of KMix. Isn't this screenshot a much more reasonable one?

I have quite a lot of volume sliders, because that's what my simple integrated audio card offers. The window should indeed be wide enough, but rotating the sliders doesn't look like a good approach to me.

As of a QDial -- we're designing an application for a computer, not a physical device. It's sompletely normal to grab a physical gnob by two fingers and tweak it, but completely alien to do the same with a QDial. Oh, and all of the professioal audio equipment where one has to move several "knobs" would use linear (in the geometric sense, not in actual gain/attenuation) controls.

> I also think it’s a lot more common to have those mixers vertically laid out.

> what about the main mixer popup?
A bit out of my scope for now: I was just interested in fixing the default size of KMix window

> With this (crap) removed and only ALSA you have a lot more controls per tab, so you might get height problems with these small 16:9 displays used nowadays.
